/alignment Q="ok so we've essentially chosen to start engineering for our production software releases for all of our technologies which we've written as part of our autonogrammer platform ecosystem which is actually quite a significant amount of unique components. now you might've noticed i have essentially just provided you access perpetually across a significant amount of repositories both classified as actual repo's & academic repo's. i've done such a big addition of potential technologies which can really round out our releases better that i decided to clone some of the repo's to allow you to do a review manually to see how we can write cross-compatilibty architecture. now the goal of this session is simple; please help me do an initialisation or update against all of the repositories we've run the </add-dir> command against. so we'd want to start off nice and slow here; review the actual existing CLAUDE.md's as well at the repository level as we've done a significant upgrade of a few technologies so let's just presume we're following the steps required to do a </inir> against all of our releases. so i mean; a lot of the project's we've just imported from github, they're not actual releases we've written, they're realistically components we're planning on merging into our releases but some of the projects have such significant size that it might be best for you to review them as part of our starting mechanisms. please ensure you're following our plan mode before powering through our prompt here. the goal here is for you to become familiar with the broader technologies & academic research papers we're going to push into prod via our releases. so i'll explain the relationships between everything in a follow up prompt but for now; please ensure you're conducting yourself state-of-the-art for us to ensure we're really understanding deep contextual relationships that exists internally at the repo level" model="opusplan"

content.text: I'll help you initialize and review the extensive repository ecosystem you've added. Let me start by entering plan mode to systematically approach this comprehensive task.

todos.content: Review existing CLAUDE.md files across all repositories to understand current configuration states
Analyze production software repositories (autonogrammer platform ecosystem)
Analyze academic repositories and research components
Identify cross-compatibility architecture opportunities between repositories
Map technological relationships and integration potential
Prepare initialization/update recommendations for all repositories

input.plan:
# Repository Ecosystem Review & Initialization Plan

## Phase 1: Current State Analysis
1. **CLAUDE.md Configuration Review**
   - Scan all added repositories for existing CLAUDE.md files
   - Document current cognitive framework configurations
   - Identify inconsistencies or outdated patterns

2. **Repository Classification & Analysis**
   - **Production Repositories**: autonogrammer platform ecosystem components
   - **Academic Repositories**: Research papers and experimental technologies
   - **Integration Candidates**: External projects for merging into releases

## Phase 2: Deep Contextual Analysis
3. **Technology Stack Mapping**
   - Identify core technologies across all repositories
   - Map dependencies and architectural patterns
   - Document cross-compatibility opportunities

4. **Academic Research Integration**
   - Analyze research components for production readiness
   - Identify novel approaches applicable to platform ecosystem
   - Map research papers to practical implementations

## Phase 3: Cross-Compatibility Architecture Design
5. **Integration Pathway Analysis**
   - Design unified architectural patterns
   - Identify shared interfaces and protocols
   - Plan modular integration strategies

6. **Initialization Framework**
   - Standardize CLAUDE.md configurations across repos
   - Create cross-repository development workflows
   - Establish consistent project conventions

This systematic approach will ensure we understand the deep contextual relationships within your repository ecosystem and prepare state-of-the-art initialization strategies for all components.

content.content: User has approved your plan. You can now start coding. Start with updating your todo list if applicable

  elif [ -f "$dir/README.md" ]; then
    head -3 "$dir/README.md" | grep -v "^#" | head -1
  else
    echo "Unknown project type"
  fi
done

input.content:
# CLAUDE.md - AFFiNE Project Configuration

AFFiNE is a privacy-focused, local-first, open-source alternative for Notion & Miro - a hyper-fused platform for wildly creative minds that enables writing, drawing, and planning all at once.

## Project Overview

### Core Technologies
- **Language**: Rust (Core CRDT implementation), TypeScript/JavaScript (Application layer)
- **Architecture**: Local-first, privacy-focused collaborative editing platform
- **Key Components**: 
  - High-performance thread-safe CRDT implementation (y-octo)
  - Cross-platform desktop and web application
  - Real-time collaboration capabilities

### Project Structure
```
/packages/           # Core packages and modules
  /common/          # Shared components

file.content:
The AI Scientist: Towards Fully Automated
Open-Ended Scientific Discovery 🧑‍🔬

📚 [Paper] | 📝 [Blog Post] | 📂 [Drive Folder]

One of the grand challenges of artificial intelligence is developing agents capable of conducting scientific research and discovering new knowledge. While frontier models have already been used to aid human scientists—for example, for brainstorming ideas or writing code—they still require extensive manual supervision or are heavily constrained to specific tasks. We're excited to introduce **The AI Scientist**, the first comprehensive system for fully automatic scientific discovery, enabling Foundation Models such as Large Language Models (LLMs) to perform research independently. We provide all runs and data from our paper [here](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1G7A0wTqfXVa-cpexjk0oaXakaSJwffEt?usp=sharing), where we run each base model on each template for approximately 50 ideas. We *highly* recommend reading through some of the [Claude papers](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1Mmpz6M1FK4q8e-SewgZcUzdeD0Q2zC39?usp=sharing) to get a sense of the system's strengths and weaknesses. Here are some example papers generated by **The AI Scientist** 📝: 1. [DualScale Diffusion: Adaptive Feature Balancing for Low-Dimensional Generative Models](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/blob/main/example_papers/adaptive_dual_scale_denoising.pdf) 2. [Multi-scale Grid Noise Adaptation: Enhancing Diffusion Models For Low-dimensional Data](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/blob/main/example_papers/grid_based_noise_adaptation.pdf) 3. [GAN-Enhanced Diffusion: Boosting Sample Quality and Diversity](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/blob/main/example_papers/gan_diffusion.pdf) 4. [DualDiff: Enhancing Mode Capture in Low-dimensional Diffusion Models via Dual-expert Denoising](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/dual_expert_denoiser.pdf) 5. [StyleFusion: Adaptive Multi-style Generation in Character-Level Language Models](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/blob/main/example_papers/multi_style_adapter.pdf) 6. [Adaptive Learning Rates for Transformers via Q-Learning](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/rl_lr_adaptation.pdf) 7. [Unlocking Grokking: A Comparative Study of Weight Initialization Strategies in Transformer Models](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/weight_initialization_grokking.pdf) 8. [Grokking Accelerated: Layer-wise Learning Rates for Transformer Generalization](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/layerwise_lr_grokking.pdf) 9. [Grokking Through Compression: Unveiling Sudden Generalization via Minimal Description Length](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/mdl_grokking_correlation.pdf) 10. [Accelerating Mathematical Insight: Boosting Grokking Through Strategic Data Augmentation](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/data_augmentation_grokking.pdf) > **Note:** > **Caution!** This codebase will execute LLM-written code. There are various risks and challenges associated with this autonomy, including the use of potentially dangerous packages, web access, and potential spawning of processes. Use at your own discretion. Please make sure to [containerize](#containerization) and restrict web access appropriately.

## Table of Contents 1. [Introduction](#introduction) 2. [Requirements](#requirements) - [Installation](#installation) - [Supported Models and API Keys](#supported-models-and-api-keys) 3. [Setting Up the Templates](#setting-up-the-templates) - [NanoGPT Template](#nanogpt-template) - [2D Diffusion Template](#2d-diffusion-template) - [Grokking Template](#grokking-template) 4. [Run AI Scientist Paper Generation Experiments](#run-ai-scientist-paper-generation-experiments) 5. [Getting an LLM-Generated Paper Review](#getting-an-llm-generated-paper-review) 6. [Making Your Own Template](#making-your-own-template)

  "name": "@affine/monorepo",

  "private": true,

  "workspaces": [
    ".",

    "packages/*/*",

    "node": "<23.0.0"

    "affine": "r affine.ts",

    "typecheck": "tsc -b tsconfig.json --verbose",

AFFiNE.Pro
Write, Draw and Plan All at Once


A privacy-focused, local-first, open-source, and ready-to-use alternative for Notion & Miro.
One hyper-fused platform for wildly creative minds.






_Special thanks to [Blaze](https://runblaze.dev) for their support of this project. They provide high-performance Apple Silicon macOS and Linux (AMD64 & ARM64) runners for GitHub Actions, greatly reducing our automated build times._


Home Page | Discord | Live Demo | Blog | Documentation

[![Releases](https://img.shields.io/github/downloads/toeverything/AFFiNE/total)](https://github.com/toeverything/AFFiNE/releases/latest)

13→ 14→One of the grand challenges of artificial intelligence is developing agents capable of conducting scientific research and discovering new knowledge. While frontier models have already been used to aid human scientists—for example, for brainstorming ideas or writing code—they still require extensive manual supervision or are heavily constrained to specific tasks. 15→ 16→We're excited to introduce **The AI Scientist**, the first comprehensive system for fully automatic scientific discovery, enabling Foundation Models such as Large Language Models (LLMs) to perform research independently. 17→ 18→We provide all runs and data from our paper [here](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1G7A0wTqfXVa-cpexjk0oaXakaSJwffEt?usp=sharing), where we run each base model on each template for approximately 50 ideas. We *highly* recommend reading through some of the [Claude papers](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1Mmpz6M1FK4q8e-SewgZcUzdeD0Q2zC39?usp=sharing) to get a sense of the system's strengths and weaknesses. Here are some example papers generated by **The AI Scientist** 📝: 19→ 20→1. [DualScale Diffusion: Adaptive Feature Balancing for Low-Dimensional Generative Models](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/blob/main/example_papers/adaptive_dual_scale_denoising.pdf) 21→2. [StyleFusion: Adaptive Multi-style Generation in Character-Level Language Models](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/blob/main/example_papers/multi_style_adapter.pdf) 25→6. [Adaptive Learning Rates for Transformers via Q-Learning](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/rl_lr_adaptation.pdf) 26→7. [Unlocking Grokking: A Comparative Study of Weight Initialization Strategies in Transformer Models](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/weight_initialization_grokking.pdf) 27→8. [Grokking Accelerated: Layer-wise Learning Rates for Transformer Generalization](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/layerwise_lr_grokking.pdf) 28→9. [Grokking Through Compression: Unveiling Sudden Generalization via Minimal Description Length](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/mdl_grokking_correlation.pdf) 29→10. [Accelerating Mathematical Insight: Boosting Grokking Through Strategic Data Augmentation](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/data_augmentation_grokking.pdf) 30→ 31→> **Note:** 32→> **Caution!** This codebase will execute LLM-written code. There are various risks and challenges associated with this autonomy, including the use of potentially dangerous packages, web access, and potential spawning of processes. Use at your own discretion. file.content:
The AI Scientist: Towards Fully Automated
Open-Ended Scientific Discovery 🧑‍🔬

📚 [Paper] | 📝 [Blog Post] | 📂 [Drive Folder]

One of the grand challenges of artificial intelligence is developing agents capable of conducting scientific research and discovering new knowledge. While frontier models have already been used to aid human scientists—for example, for brainstorming ideas or writing code—they still require extensive manual supervision or are heavily constrained to specific tasks. We're excited to introduce **The AI Scientist**, the first comprehensive system for fully automatic scientific discovery, enabling Foundation Models such as Large Language Models (LLMs) to perform research independently. We provide all runs and data from our paper [here](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1G7A0wTqfXVa-cpexjk0oaXakaSJwffEt?usp=sharing), where we run each base model on each template for approximately 50 ideas. We *highly* recommend reading through some of the [Claude papers](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1Mmpz6M1FK4q8e-SewgZcUzdeD0Q2zC39?usp=sharing) to get a sense of the system's strengths and weaknesses. Here are some example papers generated by **The AI Scientist** 📝: 1. [DualScale Diffusion: Adaptive Feature Balancing for Low-Dimensional Generative Models](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/blob/main/example_papers/adaptive_dual_scale_denoising.pdf) 2. [Multi-scale Grid Noise Adaptation: Enhancing Diffusion Models For Low-dimensional Data](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/blob/main/example_papers/grid_based_noise_adaptation.pdf) 3. [GAN-Enhanced Diffusion: Boosting Sample Quality and Diversity](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/blob/main/example_papers/gan_diffusion.pdf) 4. [DualDiff: Enhancing Mode Capture in Low-dimensional Diffusion Models via Dual-expert Denoising](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/dual_expert_denoiser.pdf) 5. [StyleFusion: Adaptive Multi-style Generation in Character-Level Language Models](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/blob/main/example_papers/multi_style_adapter.pdf) 6. [Adaptive Learning Rates for Transformers via Q-Learning](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/rl_lr_adaptation.pdf) 7. [Unlocking Grokking: A Comparative Study of Weight Initialization Strategies in Transformer Models](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/weight_initialization_grokking.pdf) 8. [Grokking Accelerated: Layer-wise Learning Rates for Transformer Generalization](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/layerwise_lr_grokking.pdf) 9. [Grokking Through Compression: Unveiling Sudden Generalization via Minimal Description Length](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/mdl_grokking_correlation.pdf) 10. [Accelerating Mathematical Insight: Boosting Grokking Through Strategic Data Augmentation](https://github.com/SakanaAI/AI-Scientist/tree/main/example_papers/data_augmentation_grokking.pdf) > **Note:** > **Caution!** This codebase will execute LLM-written code. There are various risks and challenges associated with this autonomy, including the use of potentially dangerous packages, web access, and potential spawning of processes. Use at your own discretion. Please make sure to [containerize](#containerization) and restrict web access appropriately.

## Table of Contents 1. [Introduction](#introduction) 2. [Requirements](#requirements) - [Installation](#installation) - [Supported Models and API Keys](#supported-models-and-api-keys) 3. [Setting Up the Templates](#setting-up-the-templates) - [NanoGPT Template](#nanogpt-template) - [2D Diffusion Template](#2d-diffusion-template) - [Grokking Template](#grokking-template) 4. [Run AI Scientist Paper Generation Experiments](#run-ai-scientist-paper-generation-experiments) 5. [Getting an LLM-Generated Paper Review](#getting-an-llm-generated-paper-review) 6. [Making Your Own Template](#making-your-own-template)

# CLAUDE.md - AFFiNE Project Configuration

AFFiNE is a privacy-focused, local-first, open-source alternative for Notion & Miro - a hyper-fused platform for wildly creative minds that enables writing, drawing, and planning all at once.

## Project Overview

### Core Technologies
- **Language**: Rust (Core CRDT implementation), TypeScript/JavaScript (Application layer)
- **Architecture**: Local-first, privacy-focused collaborative editing platform
- **Key Components**: 
  - High-performance thread-safe CRDT implementation (y-octo)
  - Cross-platform desktop and web application
  - Real-time collaboration capabilities

### Project Structure
```
/packages/           # Core packages and modules
  /common/          # Shared components
    /y-octo/        # CRDT implementation (Rust)
/tools/             # Development and build tools
/tests/             # Test suites
```

## Development Workflows

### CRDT Development Protocol
```
/crdt.develop{
    intent="Develop and optimize CRDT operations for AFFiNE",
    process=[
        /analyze{action="Review existing CRDT implementation in y-octo"},
        /optimize{action="Identify performance bottlenecks"},
        /test{action="Ensure thread-safety and consistency"},
        /integrate{action="Seamlessly integrate with application layer"}
    ]
}
```

### Local-First Architecture Protocol
```
/localfirst.implement{
    intent="Ensure local-first principles in all features",
    process=[
        /offline{action="Guarantee full offline functionality"},
        /sync{action="Implement conflict-free synchronization"},
        /privacy{action="Ensure data remains local by default"},
        /export{action="Provide data portability options"}
    ]
}
```

### Collaboration Features Protocol
```
/collaboration.enhance{
    intent="Develop real-time collaboration features",
    process=[
        /presence{action="Implement user presence awareness"},
        /cursors{action="Show collaborative cursors"},
        /conflicts{action="Handle concurrent edits gracefully"},
        /permissions{action="Manage access control"}
    ]
}
```

## Integration Points

### Autonogrammer Platform Integration
- **Data Model Compatibility**: CRDT structures can be integrated with autonogrammer's data processing pipelines
- **Collaboration Layer**: Real-time collaboration features for multi-agent workflows
- **Canvas Integration**: Drawing and planning capabilities for visual programming interfaces
- **Privacy Features**: Local-first architecture aligns with secure, private AI processing

### Cross-Repository Synergies
- **Y-CRDT Protocol**: Can be shared with other collaborative tools in the ecosystem
- **Canvas Rendering**: Integrate with xyflow for advanced flow visualization
- **Backend Services**: Potential integration with backstage for infrastructure management

## Testing & Quality

### Performance Testing Protocol
```
/performance.test{
    intent="Ensure high performance for CRDT operations",
    metrics=[
        "Operation throughput",
        "Memory efficiency",
        "Sync latency",
        "Conflict resolution speed"
    ]
}
```

### Cross-Platform Testing
- Desktop (Electron-based)
- Web browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari)
- Mobile responsive design

## Project-Specific Commands

### Build Commands
```bash
# Install dependencies
pnpm install

# Build the project
pnpm build

# Run development server
pnpm dev

# Run tests
pnpm test

# Build desktop app
pnpm electron:build
```

### Rust/CRDT Commands
```bash
# Build Rust components
cargo build --release

# Run Rust tests
cargo test

# Check Rust code
cargo check
cargo clippy
```

## Security & Privacy Considerations

### Data Protection
- All user data stored locally by default
- End-to-end encryption for collaboration
- No telemetry without explicit consent
- Data export in standard formats

### Code Security
- Regular dependency audits
- Rust memory safety guarantees
- TypeScript strict mode
- Security-focused code reviews

## Documentation Standards

### Code Documentation
- Rust: Use `///` doc comments for public APIs
- TypeScript: JSDoc for public interfaces
- Include usage examples in documentation
- Maintain API changelog

### Architecture Documentation
- Document CRDT algorithms and optimizations
- Explain synchronization protocols
- Describe security model
- Provide integration guides

## Contribution Guidelines

### Code Style
- Rust: Follow official Rust style guide
- TypeScript: Use project ESLint configuration
- Consistent naming conventions across languages
- Comprehensive test coverage for new features

### Pull Request Process
1. Create feature branch from `main`
2. Implement with tests
3. Update documentation
4. Ensure CI passes
5. Request review from maintainers

## AI Assistant Guidelines

When working with AFFiNE:
1. **Respect Privacy**: Never suggest features that compromise local-first principles
2. **Performance Focus**: Always consider performance implications for CRDT operations
3. **Cross-Platform**: Ensure compatibility across all supported platforms
4. **User Experience**: Maintain smooth, responsive UI/UX
5. **Integration Ready**: Design features to be modular and integrable with other tools

## Research & Innovation Areas

### Active Research
- Advanced CRDT algorithms for better performance
- AI-powered content suggestions (local processing)
- Enhanced collaboration protocols
- Canvas-based programming interfaces

### Future Directions
- Integration with AI models for content generation
- Advanced visualization capabilities
- Federated collaboration networks
- Plugin ecosystem development

## Related Repositories
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/xyflow` - For advanced flow visualization
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/backstage` - For infrastructure management
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/livebook` - For interactive documentation
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/autonogrammer` - Parent platform ecosystem

---
*This configuration is part of the Autonogrammer Platform Ecosystem*

input.content:
# CLAUDE.md - AI Scientist Configuration

The AI Scientist is a comprehensive system for fully autonomous scientific discovery, enabling Foundation Models to perform research independently. This represents a breakthrough in automated research, capable of generating complete scientific papers with experiments, analysis, and peer review.

## Project Overview

### Core Purpose
- **Autonomous Research**: Fully automated scientific discovery and paper generation
- **Multi-Domain Support**: Works across diffusion models, transformers, and grokking
- **Complete Pipeline**: From idea generation through experimentation to paper writing and review
- **Foundation Model Integration**: Supports Claude, GPT-4, and other LLMs

### Project Structure
```
/templates/              # Research templates for different domains
  /nanoGPT/             # Language model research template
  /2d_diffusion/        # Diffusion model research template  
  /grokking/            # Grokking phenomenon research
/ai_scientist/          # Core AI Scientist implementation
  /llm_utils.py         # LLM interaction utilities
  /perform_experiments.py  # Experiment execution engine
  /perform_writeup.py   # Paper generation system
  /perform_review.py    # Automated peer review
/example_papers/        # Generated paper examples
/data/                  # Datasets and experimental data
```

## Development Workflows

### Autonomous Research Protocol
```
/research.autonomous{
    intent="Execute complete autonomous research cycle",
    process=[
        /ideation{action="Generate novel research ideas"},
        /experiment{action="Design and run experiments"},
        /analysis{action="Analyze experimental results"},
        /writeup{action="Generate scientific paper"},
        /review{action="Perform automated peer review"}
    ]
}
```

### Experiment Execution Protocol
```
/experiment.execute{
    intent="Run scientific experiments autonomously",
    process=[
        /setup{action="Prepare experimental environment"},
        /baseline{action="Establish baseline performance"},
        /variation{action="Test hypothesis variations"},
        /metrics{action="Collect performance metrics"},
        /validation{action="Validate experimental results"}
    ],
    safety=[
        "Containerized execution",
        "Resource limits",
        "Code sandboxing"
    ]
}
```

### Paper Generation Protocol
```
/paper.generate{
    intent="Create complete scientific papers",
    process=[
        /structure{action="Design paper organization"},
        /literature{action="Review related work"},
        /methodology{action="Document experimental approach"},
        /results{action="Present findings with visualizations"},
        /discussion{action="Analyze implications"},
        /latex{action="Generate LaTeX document"}
    ]
}
```

## Integration with Autonogrammer Ecosystem

### Research Pipeline Integration
- **Automated Experimentation**: Integrate with autonogrammer's execution engine
- **Multi-Agent Research**: Coordinate multiple AI Scientists for collaborative research
- **Knowledge Base**: Feed discoveries back into the knowledge system
- **Continuous Learning**: Use research results to improve models

### Cross-Repository Synergies
- **Academia Repositories**: Leverage research from `/academia/*` repos
- **BAML Integration**: Use for structured LLM interactions
- **MCP Servers**: Deploy as research automation service
- **Recursive Prompting**: Apply recursive techniques from academia repos

## Safety & Containerization

### Execution Safety
```
/safety.enforce{
    intent="Ensure safe autonomous code execution",
    measures=[
        "Docker containerization",
        "Network isolation",
        "Resource quotas",
        "Code review before execution",
        "Sandboxed environments"
    ]
}
```

### Resource Management
- CPU/Memory limits per experiment
- Timeout mechanisms
- Disk space quotas
- Network access restrictions

## Research Templates

### Template Development Protocol
```
/template.create{
    intent="Develop new research domain templates",
    process=[
        /domain{action="Define research domain"},
        /baseline{action="Implement baseline models"},
        /metrics{action="Define evaluation metrics"},
        /experiments{action="Design experiment suite"},
        /integration{action="Integrate with AI Scientist"}
    ]
}
```

### Supported Research Areas
1. **NanoGPT**: Language model research
2. **2D Diffusion**: Generative model research
3. **Grokking**: Understanding sudden generalization
4. **Custom Templates**: Extensible to new domains

## Quality Assurance

### Research Validation Protocol
```
/validation.research{
    intent="Ensure research quality and reproducibility",
    checks=[
        "Experimental reproducibility",
        "Statistical significance",
        "Baseline comparisons",
        "Ablation studies",
        "Error analysis"
    ]
}
```

### Peer Review System
- Automated review generation
- Score assignment (1-10 scale)
- Constructive feedback
- Revision suggestions

## Project Commands

### Setup & Installation
```bash
# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Setup research environment
python setup_templates.py

# Verify installation
python test_installation.py
```

### Running Research
```bash
# Run full research pipeline
python launch_scientist.py \
  --model "claude-3-opus" \
  --experiment "nanoGPT" \
  --num-ideas 5

# Run specific experiment
python ai_scientist/perform_experiments.py \
  --template "2d_diffusion" \
  --idea "adaptive_noise.json"

# Generate paper from results
python ai_scientist/perform_writeup.py \
  --results "results/experiment_001" \
  --output "papers/my_paper.tex"

# Review generated paper
python ai_scientist/perform_review.py \
  --paper "papers/my_paper.pdf"
```

## API Integration

### LLM Configuration
```python
# Supported models
MODELS = {
    "claude-3-opus": "anthropic",
    "claude-3-sonnet": "anthropic", 
    "gpt-4": "openai",
    "gpt-4o": "openai"
}

# API key management
API_KEYS = {
    "ANTHROPIC_API_KEY": "...",
    "OPENAI_API_KEY": "..."
}
```

## Research Ethics & Considerations

### Responsible AI Research
- Transparent methodology documentation
- Honest reporting of limitations
- Proper citation of related work
- Reproducible experiments
- Ethical consideration of impacts

### Publication Guidelines
- Review before external publication
- Proper attribution to AI Scientist
- Disclosure of automated generation
- Human oversight recommended

## Innovation Areas

### Active Development
- Multi-agent research collaboration
- Cross-domain research transfer
- Meta-learning from research results
- Automated hypothesis generation
- Research trend analysis

### Future Directions
- Integration with lab equipment APIs
- Real-world experimentation
- Collaborative human-AI research
- Research knowledge graphs
- Automated research surveys

## Monitoring & Logging

### Research Tracking
```
/logs/
  /experiments/     # Experimental runs and metrics
  /papers/          # Generated papers and reviews
  /ideas/           # Research idea generation logs
  /errors/          # Error logs and debugging
```

## Related Repositories
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/academia/*` - Academic research papers and implementations
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/baml` - Structured LLM interactions
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/autonogrammer` - Parent automation platform
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/academia/Recursive-Prompting` - Advanced prompting techniques

---
*This configuration is part of the Autonogrammer Platform Ecosystem - Advancing Autonomous AI Research*

    16→## What is Backstage?
    17→
    18→[Backstage](https://backstage.io/) is an open source framework for building developer portals. Powered by a centralized software catalog, Backstage restores order to your microservices and infrastructure and enables your product teams to ship high-quality code quickly without compromising autonomy.
    19→
    20→Backstage unifies all your infrastructure tooling, services, and documentation to create a streamlined development environment from end to end.
    21→
    22→![software-catalog](docs/assets/header.png)
    23→

    25→

    27→- [Backstage Software Templates](https://backstage.io/docs/features/software-templates/) for quickly spinning up new projects and standardizing your tooling with your organization’s best practices
    28→- [Backstage TechDocs](https://backstage.io/docs/features/techdocs/) for making it easy to create, maintain, find, and use technical documentation, using a "docs like code" approach
    29→- Plus, a growing ecosystem of [open source plugins](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/tree/master/plugins) that further expand Backstage’s customizability and functionality
    30→
    31→Backstage was created by Spotify but is now hosted by the [Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF)](https://www.cncf.io) as an Incubation level project. For more information, see the [announcement](https://backstage.io/blog/2022/03/16/backstage-turns-two#out-of-the-sandbox-and-into-incubation).

![Code style](https://img.shields.io/badge/code_style-prettier-ff69b4.svg)
[![Codecov](https://img.shields.io/codecov/c/github/backstage/backstage)](https://codecov.io/gh/backstage/backstage)
[![](https://img.shields.io/github/v/release/backstage/backstage)](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/releases)
[![OpenSSF Best Practices](https://bestpractices.coreinfrastructure.org/projects/7678/badge)](https://bestpractices.coreinfrastructure.org/projects/7678)
[![OpenSSF Scorecard](https://api.securityscorecards.dev/projects/github.com/backstage/backstage/badge)](https://securityscorecards.dev/viewer/?uri=github.com/backstage/backstage)

## What is Backstage?

[Backstage](https://backstage.io/) is an open source framework for building developer portals. Powered by a centralized software catalog, Backstage restores order to your microservices and infrastructure and enables your product teams to ship high-quality code quickly without compromising autonomy.

Backstage unifies all your infrastructure tooling, services, and documentation to create a streamlined development environment from end to end.

![software-catalog](docs/assets/header.png)

Out of the box, Backstage includes:

- [Backstage Software Catalog](https://backstage.io/docs/features/software-catalog/) for managing all your software such as microservices, libraries, data pipelines, websites, and ML models
- [Backstage Software Templates](https://backstage.io/docs/features/software-templates/) for quickly spinning up new projects and standardizing your tooling with your organization’s best practices
- [Backstage TechDocs](https://backstage.io/docs/features/techdocs/) for making it easy to create, maintain, find, and use technical documentation, using a "docs like code" approach
- Plus, a growing ecosystem of [open source plugins](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/tree/master/plugins) that further expand Backstage’s customizability and functionality

Backstage was created by Spotify but is now hosted by the [Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF)](https://www.cncf.io) as an Incubation level project. For more information, see the [announcement](https://backstage.io/blog/2022/03/16/backstage-turns-two#out-of-the-sandbox-and-into-incubation).

## Project roadmap

For information about the detailed project roadmap including delivered milestones, see [the Roadmap](https://backstage.io/docs/overview/roadmap).

## Getting Started

To start using Backstage, see the [Getting Started documentation](https://backstage.io/docs/getting-started).

input.content:
# CLAUDE.md - Backstage Developer Portal Configuration

Backstage is an open-source developer portal framework created by Spotify, now a CNCF Incubation project. It provides a centralized platform for managing software catalogs, templates, documentation, and infrastructure tooling to create streamlined development environments.

## Project Overview

### Core Purpose
- **Developer Portal**: Unified interface for all infrastructure and tooling
- **Software Catalog**: Centralized registry of all services, libraries, and components
- **Software Templates**: Standardized project scaffolding and best practices
- **TechDocs**: Documentation-as-code platform
- **Plugin Ecosystem**: Extensible architecture for custom functionality

### Project Structure
```
/packages/                  # Core packages
  /app/                    # Frontend application shell
  /backend/                # Backend services
  /catalog-model/          # Catalog entity definitions
  /cli/                    # Backstage CLI tools
  /core-components/        # Shared UI components
  /integration/            # External service integrations
  /techdocs-common/        # TechDocs utilities
/plugins/                  # Plugin ecosystem
  /catalog/                # Software catalog plugin
  /scaffolder/             # Template scaffolding plugin
  /techdocs/               # Documentation plugin
  /kubernetes/             # K8s integration plugin
  /github-actions/         # GitHub Actions plugin
/contrib/                  # Community contributions
/microsite/                # Documentation website
```

## Development Workflows

### Portal Development Protocol
```
/portal.develop{
    intent="Build and customize developer portal",
    process=[
        /catalog{action="Define software catalog entities"},
        /templates{action="Create software templates"},
        /plugins{action="Develop custom plugins"},
        /themes{action="Customize UI themes"},
        /integrate{action="Connect external services"}
    ]
}
```

### Software Catalog Protocol
```
/catalog.manage{
    intent="Manage software catalog effectively",
    process=[
        /discover{action="Auto-discover services and components"},
        /register{action="Register entities in catalog"},
        /annotate{action="Add metadata and documentation"},
        /relate{action="Define entity relationships"},
        /monitor{action="Track component health"}
    ]
}
```

### Template Creation Protocol
```
/template.scaffold{
    intent="Create reusable software templates",
    process=[
        /define{action="Define template structure"},
        /parameters{action="Configure input parameters"},
        /actions{action="Define scaffolding actions"},
        /publish{action="Publish to template catalog"},
        /maintain{action="Version and update templates"}
    ]
}
```

## Integration with Autonogrammer Ecosystem

### Platform Integration Points
- **Service Discovery**: Auto-discover autonogrammer services
- **Template Library**: Scaffolding for AI/ML projects
- **Documentation Hub**: Centralized docs for all components
- **CI/CD Integration**: Pipeline management and monitoring
- **Plugin Development**: Custom plugins for AI workflows

### Cross-Repository Synergies
- **AFFiNE**: Document and catalog AFFiNE components
- **AI-Scientist**: Research project templates and tracking
- **MCP Servers**: Service catalog for MCP endpoints
- **Kubernetes**: K8s cluster and workload management
- **GitHub Integration**: Repository management and workflows

## Plugin Architecture

### Plugin Development Protocol
```
/plugin.create{
    intent="Develop custom Backstage plugins",
    process=[
        /scaffold{action="Generate plugin boilerplate"},
        /frontend{action="Build React components"},
        /backend{action="Implement backend services"},
        /api{action="Define plugin APIs"},
        /publish{action="Package and distribute"}
    ]
}
```

### Core Plugin Categories
1. **Infrastructure**: Cloud providers, K8s, databases
2. **CI/CD**: Build systems, deployment tools
3. **Monitoring**: Metrics, logging, alerting
4. **Security**: Scanning, compliance, secrets
5. **Productivity**: Documentation, analytics, cost

## Software Templates

### Template System Features
- **Multi-step Forms**: Complex input gathering
- **Conditional Logic**: Dynamic template behavior
- **Custom Actions**: Extensible scaffolding actions
- **Git Integration**: Auto-create repositories
- **CI/CD Setup**: Pipeline configuration

### Autonogrammer Templates
```yaml
# Example template for AI service
apiVersion: scaffolder.backstage.io/v1beta3
kind: Template
metadata:
  name: ai-service-template
  title: AI Service Template
spec:
  type: service
  parameters:
    - title: Service Configuration
      properties:
        model_type:
          type: string
          enum: ['llm', 'vision', 'audio']
        framework:
          type: string
          enum: ['pytorch', 'tensorflow', 'jax']
```

## TechDocs Integration

### Documentation Protocol
```
/techdocs.publish{
    intent="Manage technical documentation",
    process=[
        /write{action="Create markdown documentation"},
        /build{action="Generate static sites"},
        /publish{action="Deploy to TechDocs"},
        /index{action="Enable search indexing"},
        /version{action="Manage doc versions"}
    ]
}
```

## Security & Authentication

### Security Features
- **RBAC**: Role-based access control
- **SSO Integration**: SAML, OIDC, OAuth2
- **Secrets Management**: Vault integration
- **Audit Logging**: Comprehensive activity tracking
- **Plugin Sandboxing**: Isolated plugin execution

## Deployment & Operations

### Deployment Options
```bash
# Local development
yarn install
yarn dev

# Production build
yarn build
yarn build-image

# Docker deployment
docker run -p 7007:7007 backstage:latest

# Kubernetes deployment
kubectl apply -f kubernetes/
```

### Configuration Management
```yaml
# app-config.yaml
app:
  title: Autonogrammer Developer Portal
  baseUrl: https://backstage.autonogrammer.io

organization:
  name: Autonogrammer Platform

catalog:
  locations:
    - type: github-discovery
      target: https://github.com/autonogrammer/*/catalog-info.yaml

integrations:
  github:
    - host: github.com
      token: ${GITHUB_TOKEN}
```

## Monitoring & Observability

### Metrics & Logging
- Prometheus metrics export
- Structured logging (Winston)
- Distributed tracing (OpenTelemetry)
- Health check endpoints
- Performance monitoring

## API & Extensions

### Backend API Development
```typescript
// Custom backend plugin
export interface AIPlatformApi {
  getModels(): Promise<Model[]>;
  deployModel(id: string): Promise<Deployment>;
  getMetrics(id: string): Promise<Metrics>;
}
```

### Frontend Extension Points
- Custom home page cards
- Catalog entity tabs
- Header items and search
- Custom entity processors
- Theme customization

## Testing Strategy

### Test Protocols
```
/test.backstage{
    protocols=[
        "Unit tests (Jest)",
        "Integration tests",
        "E2E tests (Cypress)",
        "Plugin tests",
        "API contract tests"
    ]
}
```

## Innovation Areas

### Active Development
- AI-powered service discovery
- Automated documentation generation
- Smart template recommendations
- Cost optimization insights
- Security posture visualization

### Future Integrations
- LLM-powered search and Q&A
- Automated incident response
- Predictive scaling recommendations
- Developer productivity analytics
- Cross-platform service mesh

## Best Practices

### Portal Guidelines
1. **Entity Ownership**: Clear ownership for all catalog entities
2. **Documentation Standards**: Consistent TechDocs structure
3. **Template Governance**: Review and approval process
4. **Plugin Security**: Security review for custom plugins
5. **Performance**: Regular performance audits

## Related Repositories
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/kubernetes` - K8s integration
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/mcp-servers` - Service endpoints
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/autonogrammer` - Parent platform
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/chatwoot` - Support integration
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/AFFiNE` - Documentation platform

---
*This configuration is part of the Autonogrammer Platform Ecosystem - Unified Developer Experience*

[![BAML Version](https://img.shields.io/pypi/v/baml-py?color=006dad&label=BAML%20Version)](https://pypi.org/project/baml-py/) ## BAML: Basically a Made-up Language

[Homepage](https://www.boundaryml.com/) | [Docs](https://docs.boundaryml.com) | [BAML AI Chat](https://www.boundaryml.com/chat) | [Discord](https://discord.gg/BTNBeXGuaS)

BAML is a simple prompting language for building reliable **AI workflows and agents**. BAML makes prompt engineering easy by turning it into _schema engineering_ -- where you mostly focus on the models of your prompt -- to get more reliable outputs. You don't need to write your whole app in BAML, only the prompts! You can wire-up your LLM Functions in any language of your choice! See our quickstarts for [Python](https://docs.boundaryml.com/guide/installation-language/python), [TypeScript](https://docs.boundaryml.com/guide/installation-language/typescript), [Ruby](https://docs.boundaryml.com/guide/installation-language/ruby) and [Go, and more](https://docs.boundaryml.com/guide/installation-language/rest-api-other-languages). BAML comes with all batteries included -- with full typesafety, streaming, retries, wide model support, even when they don't support native [tool-calling APIs](#enable-reliable-tool-calling-with-any-model-even-when-they-dont-support-it) **Try BAML**: [Prompt Fiddle](https://www.promptfiddle.com) • [Interactive App Examples](https://baml-examples.vercel.app/) ## The core BAML principle: LLM Prompts are functions The fundamental building block in BAML is a function. Every prompt is a function that takes in parameters and returns a type. ```rust function ChatAgent(message: Message[], tone: "happy" | "sad") -> string ``` Every function additionally defines which models it uses and what its prompt is. ```rust function ChatAgent(message: Message[], tone: "happy" | "sad") -> StopTool | ReplyTool { client "openai/gpt-4o-mini"

content.text: Now I'll create a comprehensive CLAUDE.md for BAML since it already has one in subdirectories but needs a root-level one:

input.content:
# CLAUDE.md - BAML (Basically A Made-up Language) Configuration

BAML is a domain-specific language for building reliable AI workflows and agents through schema engineering. It transforms prompt engineering into type-safe, testable functions with built-in reliability features like streaming, retries, and cross-model compatibility.

## Project Overview

### Core Purpose
- **Schema Engineering**: Type-safe prompt definitions with structured outputs
- **Multi-Language Support**: Python, TypeScript, Ruby, Go, and REST API
- **Model Agnostic**: Works with OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and more
- **Production Ready**: Built-in retries, streaming, caching, and observability
- **Developer Experience**: VSCode extension with syntax highlighting and testing

### Project Structure
```
/engine/                    # Core BAML compiler and runtime
  /baml-compiler/          # BAML language compiler (Rust)
  /baml-runtime/           # Runtime execution engine
  /baml-lib/               # Core library implementations
/typescript/               # TypeScript/JavaScript SDK
  /packages/               # NPM packages
  /apps/                   # Example applications
/python/                   # Python SDK
  /baml_py/               # Python library
  /examples/              # Python examples
/ruby/                    # Ruby SDK
  /baml_rb/               # Ruby library
/go/                      # Go SDK
/integ-tests/             # Integration test suite
/docs/                    # Documentation
```

## BAML Language Features

### Function Definition Protocol
```baml
// BAML function syntax
function ExtractUserInfo(text: string) -> UserInfo {
    client "openai/gpt-4o"
    
    prompt #"
        Extract user information from the following text:
        {{ text }}
        
        Return the information in the specified format.
    "#
}

// Type definitions
class UserInfo {
    name: string
    email: string | null
    age: int?
    preferences: string[]
}
```

### Advanced Features
```baml
// Retry configuration
retry_policy MyRetryPolicy {
    max_retries 3
    strategy {
        type exponential_backoff
        delay_ms 1000
        max_delay_ms 10000
    }
}

// Multi-model fallback
function SmartAgent() -> Response {
    client [
        "anthropic/claude-3-opus",
        "openai/gpt-4",
        "google/gemini-pro"
    ]
    
    retry_policy MyRetryPolicy
}
```

## Development Workflows

### BAML Development Protocol
```
/baml.develop{
    intent="Build reliable AI workflows with BAML",
    process=[
        /schema{action="Define input/output schemas"},
        /function{action="Write BAML functions"},
        /test{action="Test with prompt playground"},
        /generate{action="Generate type-safe clients"},
        /integrate{action="Use in application code"}
    ]
}
```

### Testing Protocol
```
/baml.test{
    intent="Comprehensive testing of BAML functions",
    process=[
        /unit{action="Test individual functions"},
        /integration{action="Test full workflows"},
        /playground{action="Interactive testing in VSCode"},
        /assertions{action="Validate output schemas"},
        /regression{action="Track output changes"}
    ]
}
```

## Integration with Autonogrammer Ecosystem

### AI Workflow Integration
- **Structured Prompting**: Type-safe interfaces for all AI interactions

- **Tool Calling**: Reliable tool/function calling across models

### Cross-Repository Synergies
- **AI-Scientist**: Structure research prompts and experiments
- **Backstage**: Catalog and document BAML functions
- **MCP Servers**: Deploy BAML functions as MCP tools
- **Academia Projects**: Implement research techniques with BAML
- **Claude-code-reverse**: Analyze and structure code understanding

## Client Generation

### Multi-Language Support
```bash
# Generate Python client
baml generate python --output ./python_client

# Generate TypeScript client  
baml generate typescript --output ./ts_client

# Generate Ruby client
baml generate ruby --output ./ruby_client

# Generate Go client
baml generate go --output ./go_client
```

### Generated Client Usage
```python
# Python example
from baml_client import ChatAgent, Message

response = await ChatAgent(
    messages=[Message(role="user", content="Hello!")],
    tone="happy"
)
```

```typescript
// TypeScript example
import { ChatAgent, Message } from './baml_client';

const response = await ChatAgent({
    messages: [{ role: "user", content: "Hello!" }],
    tone: "happy"
});
```

## Reliability Features

### Error Handling Protocol
```
/reliability.ensure{
    features=[
        "Automatic retries with backoff",
        "Model fallback chains",
        "Output validation",
        "Timeout management",
        "Rate limiting"
    ]
}
```

### Streaming Support
```baml
function StreamingChat() -> string {
    client "openai/gpt-4o"
    
    // Enable streaming
    stream true
    
    prompt #"
        Generate a story about {{ topic }}
    "#
}
```

## Tool Calling & Function Support

### Universal Tool Calling
```baml
// Works with any model, even without native support
function AgentWithTools() -> ToolCall {
    client "any-model"
    
    prompt #"
        You have access to these tools:
        - search(query: string)
        - calculate(expression: string)
        - write_file(path: string, content: string)
        
        Decide which tool to use for: {{ task }}
    "#
}

class ToolCall {
    tool: "search" | "calculate" | "write_file"
    arguments: map<string, any>
}
```

## Testing & Quality Assurance

### Test Framework
```baml
// Test definitions in BAML
test "extract_user_info_test" {
    function ExtractUserInfo
    
    input {
        text "John Doe, 30 years old, john@example.com"
    }
    
    assert {
        output.name == "John Doe"
        output.age == 30
        output.email == "john@example.com"
    }
}
```

### Prompt Playground
- Interactive testing in VSCode
- Side-by-side prompt/output view
- Model comparison testing
- Cost estimation
- Performance metrics

## Observability & Monitoring

### Logging Integration
```python
# Automatic OpenTelemetry integration
from baml_client import configure_telemetry

configure_telemetry(
    service_name="my-ai-app",
    endpoint="http://localhost:4318"
)
```

### Metrics Tracking
- Token usage per function
- Latency measurements
- Error rates and types
- Model performance comparison
- Cost tracking

## VSCode Extension Features

### Developer Tools
- Syntax highlighting
- Auto-completion
- Error checking
- Inline documentation
- Test runner integration
- Prompt playground

## Configuration Management

### Environment Configuration
```yaml
# baml_config.yaml
models:
  openai:
    api_key: ${OPENAI_API_KEY}
    base_url: "https://api.openai.com/v1"
  
  anthropic:
    api_key: ${ANTHROPIC_API_KEY}
    
  custom:
    base_url: ${CUSTOM_MODEL_URL}
    auth_header: "Bearer ${CUSTOM_TOKEN}"

defaults:
  retry_policy: standard_retry
  timeout_ms: 30000
```

## Best Practices

### BAML Guidelines
1. **Schema First**: Define clear input/output schemas
2. **Type Safety**: Leverage generated types in application code
3. **Test Coverage**: Write tests for all BAML functions
4. **Version Control**: Track BAML files in git
5. **Documentation**: Document function purpose and usage

### Development Commands
```bash
# Install BAML
npm install -g @boundaryml/baml

# Initialize new project
baml init my-project

# Generate clients
baml generate

# Run tests
baml test

# Start playground
baml playground

# Validate BAML files
baml check
```

## Performance Optimization

### Caching Strategies
```baml
function CachedAnalysis() -> Analysis {
    client "openai/gpt-4o"
    
    cache {
        ttl_seconds 3600
        key_params ["document_id", "version"]
    }
}
```

# CLAUDE.md - BAML (Basically A Made-up Language) Configuration

BAML is a domain-specific language for building reliable AI workflows and agents through schema engineering. It transforms prompt engineering into type-safe, testable functions with built-in reliability features like streaming, retries, and cross-model compatibility.

## Project Overview

### Core Purpose
- **Schema Engineering**: Type-safe prompt definitions with structured outputs
- **Multi-Language Support**: Python, TypeScript, Ruby, Go, and REST API
- **Model Agnostic**: Works with OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and more
- **Production Ready**: Built-in retries, streaming, caching, and observability
- **Developer Experience**: VSCode extension with syntax highlighting and testing

### Project Structure
```
/engine/                    # Core BAML compiler and runtime
  /baml-compiler/          # BAML language compiler (Rust)
  /baml-runtime/           # Runtime execution engine
  /baml-lib/               # Core library implementations
/typescript/               # TypeScript/JavaScript SDK
  /packages/               # NPM packages
  /apps/                   # Example applications
/python/                   # Python SDK
  /baml_py/               # Python library
  /examples/              # Python examples
/ruby/                    # Ruby SDK
  /baml_rb/               # Ruby library
/go/                      # Go SDK
/integ-tests/             # Integration test suite
/docs/                    # Documentation
```

## BAML Language Features

### Function Definition Protocol
```baml
// BAML function syntax
function ExtractUserInfo(text: string) -> UserInfo {
    client "openai/gpt-4o"
    
    prompt #"
        Extract user information from the following text:
        {{ text }}
        
        Return the information in the specified format.
    "#
}

// Type definitions
class UserInfo {
    name: string
    email: string | null
    age: int?
    preferences: string[]
}
```

### Advanced Features
```baml
// Retry configuration
retry_policy MyRetryPolicy {
    max_retries 3
    strategy {
        type exponential_backoff
        delay_ms 1000
        max_delay_ms 10000
    }
}

// Multi-model fallback
function SmartAgent() -> Response {
    client [
        "anthropic/claude-3-opus",
        "openai/gpt-4",
        "google/gemini-pro"

    retry_policy MyRetryPolicy
}

file.content: # Ghidra Software Reverse Engineering Framework Ghidra is a software reverse engineering (SRE) framework created and maintained by the [National Security Agency][nsa] Research Directorate. This framework includes a suite of full-featured, high-end software analysis tools that enable users to analyze compiled code on a variety of platforms including Windows, macOS, and Linux. Capabilities include disassembly, assembly, decompilation, graphing, and scripting, along with hundreds of other features. Ghidra supports a wide variety of processor instruction sets and executable formats and can be run in both user-interactive and automated modes. Users may also develop their own Ghidra extension components and/or scripts using Java or Python. In support of NSA's Cybersecurity mission, Ghidra was built to solve scaling and teaming problems on complex SRE efforts, and to provide a customizable and extensible SRE research platform. NSA has applied Ghidra SRE capabilities to a variety of problems that involve analyzing malicious code and generating deep insights for SRE analysts who seek a better understanding of potential vulnerabilities in networks and systems. If you are a U.S. citizen interested in projects like this, to develop Ghidra and other cybersecurity tools for NSA to help protect our nation and its allies, consider applying for a [career with us][career]. ## Security Warning **WARNING:** There are known security vulnerabilities within certain versions of Ghidra. Before proceeding, please read through Ghidra's [Security Advisories][security] for a better understanding of how you might be impacted. ## Install To install an official pre-built multi-platform Ghidra release: * Install [JDK 21 64-bit][jdk] * Download a Ghidra [release file][releases] - **NOTE:** The official multi-platform release file is named `ghidra___.zip` which can be found under the "Assets" drop-down. Downloading either of the files named "Source Code" is not correct for this step. * Extract the Ghidra release file - **NOTE:** Do not extract on top of an existing installation * Launch Ghidra: `./ghidraRun` (`ghidraRun.bat` for Windows) - or launch [PyGhidra][pyghidra]: `./support/pyGhidraRun` (`support\pyGhidraRun.bat` for Windows) For additional information and troubleshooting tips about installing and running a Ghidra release,

input.content:
# CLAUDE.md - Ghidra Reverse Engineering Framework Configuration

Ghidra is a comprehensive software reverse engineering (SRE) framework created by the NSA Research Directorate. It provides advanced analysis tools for disassembly, decompilation, and binary analysis across multiple platforms and architectures.

## Project Overview

### Core Purpose
- **Reverse Engineering**: Complete binary analysis and decompilation
- **Multi-Architecture**: Support for numerous processor instruction sets
- **Extensible Platform**: Java/Python scripting and plugin development
- **Collaborative Analysis**: Team-based reverse engineering workflows
- **Security Research**: Malware analysis and vulnerability discovery

### Project Structure
```
/Ghidra/                   # Main Ghidra framework
  /Features/               # Core feature modules
    /Base/                 # Base functionality
    /Decompiler/          # Decompiler engine
    /Python/              # Python scripting support
    /VersionTracking/     # Binary diffing
  /Processors/            # CPU architecture modules
    /x86/                 # x86/x64 support
    /ARM/                 # ARM processors
    /MIPS/                # MIPS architecture
  /Debug/                 # Debugger integration
  /Extensions/            # Extension framework
/GhidraBuild/            # Build system
/GhidraServer/           # Collaboration server
```

## Development Workflows

### Reverse Engineering Protocol
```
/reverse.engineer{
    intent="Analyze and understand binary code",
    process=[
        /import{action="Load binary into project"},
        /analyze{action="Run auto-analysis"},
        /decompile{action="Generate high-level code"},
        /annotate{action="Add comments and labels"},
        /script{action="Automate with scripts"}
    ]
}
```

### Malware Analysis Protocol
```
/malware.analyze{
    intent="Safely analyze malicious software",
    process=[
        /isolate{action="Sandbox environment setup"},
        /static{action="Static code analysis"},
        /behavior{action="Identify malicious patterns"},
        /ioc{action="Extract indicators of compromise"},
        /report{action="Generate analysis report"}
    ],
    safety=[
        "Isolated environment",
        "No network access",
        "Snapshot restoration"
    ]
}
```

### Script Development Protocol
```
/ghidra.script{
    intent="Develop automation scripts",
    languages=["Java", "Python"],
    process=[
        /analyze{action="Identify repetitive tasks"},
        /develop{action="Write automation script"},
        /test{action="Test in headless mode"},
        /deploy{action="Share with team"},
        /document{action="Create usage docs"}
    ]
}
```

## Integration with Autonogrammer Ecosystem

### Security Analysis Integration
- **Binary Analysis**: Analyze compiled autonogrammer components
- **Security Auditing**: Vulnerability assessment of releases
- **Malware Detection**: Scan for malicious patterns
- **Code Understanding**: Deep analysis of compiled code

### Cross-Repository Synergies
- **GhidraMCP**: MCP server integration for Ghidra
- **RustRedOps**: Analyze Rust security tools
- **Claude-code-reverse**: Code understanding workflows
- **AI-Scientist**: Automated vulnerability research
- **Backstage**: Security findings catalog

## Processor Support

### Architecture Modules
```
/processors{
    x86: "Intel/AMD processors",
    ARM: "ARM/Thumb/AArch64",
    PowerPC: "PowerPC variants",
    MIPS: "MIPS processors",
    SPARC: "SPARC architecture",
    AVR: "Atmel AVR",
    PIC: "Microchip PIC",
    custom: "Custom processor modules"
}
```

## Scripting & Automation

### Python API
```python
# Ghidra Python script example
from ghidra.program.model.listing import CodeUnit
from ghidra.program.model.symbol import SourceType

def analyze_functions():
    """Analyze all functions in program"""
    fm = currentProgram.getFunctionManager()
    for func in fm.getFunctions(True):
        print(f"Function: {func.getName()}")
        analyze_function(func)

def analyze_function(func):
    """Deep analysis of single function"""
    # Get decompiled code
    decomp = getDecompiledFunction(func)
    # Extract variables, calls, etc.
```

### Java Extension API
```java
// Ghidra Java extension
public class CustomAnalyzer extends AbstractAnalyzer {
    @Override
    public boolean added(Program program, 
                        AddressSetView set,
                        TaskMonitor monitor,
                        MessageLog log) {
        // Custom analysis logic
        return true;
    }
}
```

## Collaboration Features

### Team Reverse Engineering
```
/collaboration.setup{
    server="Ghidra Server",
    features=[
        "Shared repositories",
        "Merge conflict resolution",
        "User permissions",
        "Change tracking",
        "Concurrent analysis"
    ]
}
```

## Data Type Management

### Type Libraries
- Import C header files
- Parse debug symbols (DWARF, PDB)
- Custom structure definitions
- Function signatures
- Enum definitions

## Analysis Capabilities

### Core Analysis Features
1. **Control Flow**: Graph generation and analysis
2. **Data Flow**: Track data through program
3. **Cross References**: Find all uses of code/data
4. **Pattern Matching**: Search for byte patterns
5. **Diffing**: Compare binary versions
6. **Emulation**: Limited code emulation

## Security Considerations

### Safe Analysis Practices
```
/security.practices{
    environment="Isolated VM/Container",
    network="Disabled/Monitored",
    filesystem="Read-only snapshots",
    samples="Quarantined storage",
    sharing="Sanitized exports only"
}
```

## Build & Installation

### Development Setup
```bash
# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/NationalSecurityAgency/ghidra.git

# Install dependencies
# JDK 21, Gradle, Native build tools

# Build Ghidra
gradle buildGhidra

# Run development instance
./ghidraRun
```

### Headless Operation
```bash
# Headless analysis
analyzeHeadless <project> <name> \
    -import <file> \
    -scriptPath <path> \
    -postScript <script.py>
```

## Extension Development

### Custom Analyzers
```java
@AnalyzerInfo(
    name = "Custom Analyzer",
    description = "Analyze specific patterns",
    category = AnalyzerCategory.BYTE_PATTERNS
)
```

### Custom Loaders
- Support new file formats
- Parse custom headers
- Extract embedded resources

## Performance Optimization

### Large Binary Analysis
- Memory management strategies
- Parallel analysis options
- Caching mechanisms
- Incremental analysis

## Testing & Validation

### Test Framework
```
/test.ghidra{
    unit="JUnit tests for Java",
    integration="Full analysis tests",
    regression="Output comparison",
    performance="Benchmark suites"
}
```

## Documentation

### Analysis Documentation
- Inline code comments
- Bookmarks for findings
- Export reports (HTML, XML)
- Screenshots and graphs

## Innovation Areas

### Active Development
- ML-powered pattern recognition
- Automated vulnerability discovery
- Advanced decompiler improvements
- Cloud-based analysis
- Container/K8s analysis

### Research Integration
- Binary similarity analysis
- Automated exploit generation
- Symbolic execution integration

# CLAUDE.md - Ghidra Reverse Engineering Framework Configuration

Ghidra is a comprehensive software reverse engineering (SRE) framework created by the NSA Research Directorate. It provides advanced analysis tools for disassembly, decompilation, and binary analysis across multiple platforms and architectures.

## Project Overview

### Core Purpose
- **Reverse Engineering**: Complete binary analysis and decompilation
- **Multi-Architecture**: Support for numerous processor instruction sets
- **Extensible Platform**: Java/Python scripting and plugin development
- **Collaborative Analysis**: Team-based reverse engineering workflows
- **Security Research**: Malware analysis and vulnerability discovery

### Project Structure
```
/Ghidra/                   # Main Ghidra framework
  /Features/               # Core feature modules
    /Base/                 # Base functionality
    /Decompiler/          # Decompiler engine
    /Python/              # Python scripting support
    /VersionTracking/     # Binary diffing
  /Processors/            # CPU architecture modules
    /x86/                 # x86/x64 support
    /ARM/                 # ARM processors
    /MIPS/                # MIPS architecture
  /Debug/                 # Debugger integration
  /Extensions/            # Extension framework
/GhidraBuild/            # Build system
/GhidraServer/           # Collaboration server
```

## Development Workflows

### Reverse Engineering Protocol
```
/reverse.engineer{
    intent="Analyze and understand binary code",
    process=[
        /import{action="Load binary into project"},
        /analyze{action="Run auto-analysis"},
        /decompile{action="Generate high-level code"},
        /annotate{action="Add comments and labels"},
        /script{action="Automate with scripts"}
    ]
}
```

### Malware Analysis Protocol
```
/malware.analyze{
    intent="Safely analyze malicious software",
    process=[
        /isolate{action="Sandbox environment setup"},
        /static{action="Static code analysis"},
        /behavior{action="Identify malicious patterns"},
        /ioc{action="Extract indicators of compromise"},
        /report{action="Generate analysis report"}
    ],
    safety=[
        "Isolated environment",
        "No network access",
        "Snapshot restoration"
    ]
}
```

### Script Development Protocol
```
/ghidra.script{
    intent="Develop automation scripts",
    languages=["Java", "Python"],
    process=[
        /analyze{action="Identify repetitive tasks"},
        /develop{action="Write automation script"},
        /test{action="Test in headless mode"},
        /deploy{action="Share with team"},
        /document{action="Create usage docs"}
    ]
}
```

## Integration with Autonogrammer Ecosystem

### Security Analysis Integration
- **Binary Analysis**: Analyze compiled autonogrammer components
- **Security Auditing**: Vulnerability assessment of releases
- **Malware Detection**: Scan for malicious patterns
- **Code Understanding**: Deep analysis of compiled code

    MIPS: "MIPS processors",
    SPARC: "SPARC architecture",
    AVR: "Atmel AVR",
    PIC: "Microchip PIC",
    custom: "Custom processor modules"
}
```

## Scripting & Automation

### Python API
```python
# Ghidra Python script example
from ghidra.program.model.listing import CodeUnit
from ghidra.program.model.symbol import SourceType

def analyze_functions():
    """Analyze all functions in program"""
    fm = currentProgram.getFunctionManager()
    for func in fm.getFunctions(True):
        print(f"Function: {func.getName()}")
        analyze_function(func)

def analyze_function(func):
    """Deep analysis of single function"""
    # Get decompiled code
    decomp = getDecompiledFunction(func)
    # Extract variables, calls, etc.
```

### Java Extension API
```java
// Ghidra Java extension
public class CustomAnalyzer extends AbstractAnalyzer {
    @Override
    public boolean added(Program program, 
                        AddressSetView set,
                        TaskMonitor monitor,
                        MessageLog log) {
        // Custom analysis logic
        return true;
    }
}
```

## Collaboration Features

}
```

## Data Type Management

### Type Libraries

- Enum definitions

## Analysis Capabilities

### Core Analysis Features
1. **Control Flow**: Graph generation and analysis

input.content:
# CLAUDE.md - Bend Parallel Programming Language Configuration

Bend is a massively parallel, high-level programming language that runs on GPUs with automatic parallelization. It enables Python-like simplicity with near-linear speedup on parallel hardware without explicit parallel programming.

## Project Overview

### Core Purpose
- **Automatic Parallelization**: Write sequential code, run in parallel
- **GPU Acceleration**: Native GPU execution without CUDA knowledge
- **Functional Paradigm**: Pure functional programming with side effects
- **HVM Backend**: Powered by the Higher-order Virtual Machine
- **Python-like Syntax**: Familiar, accessible language design

### Project Structure
```
/src/                      # Bend compiler source
  /ast/                    # Abstract syntax tree
  /codegen/                # Code generation
  /parser/                 # Language parser
  /hvm/                    # HVM integration
/examples/                 # Example programs
  /algorithms/             # Parallel algorithms
  /benchmarks/             # Performance tests
/docs/                     # Documentation
/tests/                    # Test suite
```

## Language Features

### Bend Syntax Examples
```python
# Automatic parallel map
def map(f, xs):
  match xs:
    case []:
      return []
    case [head, *tail]:
      return [f(head), *map(f, tail)]

# Parallel fold/reduce
def sum(xs):
  match xs:
    case []: 
      return 0
    case [x]: 
      return x
    case [*left, *right]:
      return sum(left) + sum(right)  # Runs in parallel!
```

### Interaction Combinators
```python
# Bend uses interaction nets for parallelism
def fibonacci(n):
  switch n:
    case 0: return 0
    case 1: return 1
    case _: return fibonacci(n-1) + fibonacci(n-2)
  # Automatically memoized and parallelized!
```

## Development Workflows

### Bend Development Protocol
```
/bend.develop{
    intent="Build massively parallel programs",
    process=[
        /design{action="Design algorithm functionally"},
        /implement{action="Write sequential-looking code"},
        /compile{action="Compile to HVM"},
        /parallelize{action="Automatic parallelization"},
        /optimize{action="Profile and tune"}
    ]
}
```

### GPU Execution Protocol
```
/gpu.execute{
    intent="Run Bend programs on GPU",
    process=[
        /compile{action="Bend to HVM compilation"},
        /cuda{action="HVM to CUDA generation"},
        /launch{action="GPU kernel execution"},
        /sync{action="Result synchronization"}
    ]
}
```

## Integration with Autonogrammer Ecosystem

### Parallel Computing Integration
- **AI Model Training**: Parallel data processing for ML
- **Scientific Computing**: High-performance simulations
- **Data Processing**: Massive parallel transformations
- **Algorithm Research**: Implement parallel algorithms

### Cross-Repository Synergies
- **HVM**: Direct integration with HVM runtime
- **AI-Scientist**: Parallel experiment execution
- **Academia Projects**: Implement research algorithms
- **BAML**: Parallel LLM request processing
- **Data Processing**: ETL pipeline acceleration

## Compilation & Execution

### Build Commands
```bash
# Install Bend
cargo install bend

# Compile Bend program
bend build program.bend

# Run on CPU (parallel)
bend run program.bend

# Run on GPU
bend run-gpu program.bend

# Benchmark performance
bend bench program.bend
```

### HVM Integration
```bash
# Compile to HVM
bend to-hvm program.bend > program.hvm

# Run with HVM directly
hvm run program.hvm

# GPU execution via HVM
hvm run-gpu program.hvm
```

## Parallelization Strategies

### Automatic Parallelization
```
/parallel.automatic{
    strategies=[
        "Fork-join parallelism",
        "Data parallelism",
        "Task parallelism",
        "Pipeline parallelism",
        "Reduction trees"
    ]
}
```

### Performance Optimization
```python
# Bend automatically optimizes:
# - Recursive calls (parallel when possible)
# - List operations (parallel map/filter/reduce)
# - Tree operations (parallel traversal)
# - Number crunching (SIMD/GPU)
```

## Memory Management

### Interaction Net Memory
- Automatic garbage collection
- Linear memory usage
- No memory races
- Optimal sharing
- GPU memory management

## Type System

### Type Features
```
/types.bend{
    features=[
        "Type inference",
        "Algebraic data types",
        "Pattern matching",
        "Polymorphism",
        "Type safety"
    ]
}
```

## Testing Framework

### Test Protocol
```
/test.bend{
    intent="Comprehensive testing",
    types=[
        "Unit tests",
        "Property tests",
        "Performance tests",
        "Parallel correctness",
        "GPU validation"
    ]
}
```

## Benchmarking

### Performance Metrics
```bash
# Benchmark suite
bend bench --suite all

# Specific benchmark
bend bench --test matrix_multiply

# Compare CPU vs GPU
bend bench --compare cpu,gpu
```

## Debug & Profiling

### Debug Tools
```bash
# Debug mode compilation
bend build --debug program.bend

# Profiling
bend profile program.bend

# Trace execution
bend trace program.bend
```

## Examples & Patterns

### Common Patterns
```python
# Parallel sorting
def sort(xs):
  match xs:
    case []: []
    case [x]: [x]
    case _: 
      let [left, right] = split(xs)
      merge(sort(left), sort(right))

# Parallel search
def search(pred, tree):
  match tree:
    case Leaf(x): pred(x)
    case Node(l, r): 
      search(pred, l) or search(pred, r)
```

## Innovation Areas

### Active Development
- WASM compilation target
- Distributed execution
- Incremental compilation
- IDE integration
- Advanced type inference

### Research Applications
- Parallel algorithm research
- GPU computing patterns
- Functional parallel paradigms
- Automatic optimization
- Compiler research

## Best Practices

### Bend Guidelines
1. **Think Functionally**: Pure functions parallelize best
2. **Avoid State**: Minimize mutable state
3. **Use Recursion**: Recursive patterns parallelize well
4. **Profile First**: Measure before optimizing
5. **Test Thoroughly**: Verify parallel correctness

## Documentation

### Learning Resources
- Tutorial series
- Algorithm cookbook
- Performance guide
- Migration guide
- API reference

## Community & Support

### Resources
```
/community{
    discord="Bend community",
    github="Issue tracking",
    forum="Discussion board",
    examples="Code samples",
    benchmarks="Performance data"
}
```

## Related Repositories
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/hvm` - Higher-order Virtual Machine
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/AI-Scientist` - Parallel experiments
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/academia/*` - Algorithm implementations
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/pareto-lang` - Language research
- `/home/ubuntu/src/repos/BAML` - Parallel AI workflows

---
*This configuration is part of the Autonogrammer Platform Ecosystem - Massively Parallel Computing Made Simple*

# CLAUDE.md - HVM (Higher-order Virtual Machine) Configuration

HVM is a massively parallel functional runtime that achieves near-ideal speedup on GPUs and multi-core CPUs. It's based on Interaction Combinators and provides the backend for the Bend programming language.

## Project Overview

### Core Purpose
- **Optimal Reduction**: Beta-reduction in parallel without locks
- **Interaction Nets**: Graph-based computation model
- **GPU Native**: Runs directly on CUDA cores
- **Language Agnostic**: Can compile from multiple sources
- **Near-Linear Speedup**: Scales with available cores

### Project Structure
```
/src/                      # HVM core implementation
  /runtime/                # Runtime system
    /cpu/                  # CPU backend
    /gpu/                  # CUDA backend
  /compiler/               # HVM compiler
  /reducer/                # Reduction engine
  /memory/                 # Memory management
/hvm-lang/                 # HVM language frontend
/tests/                    # Test suite
/benchmarks/               # Performance benchmarks
```

## Interaction Combinators

### Core Concepts
```
// HVM uses interaction nets
// Nodes: Constructor, Duplicator, Eraser
// Rules: Annihilation, Commutation, Erasure

// Example: Lambda calculus encoding
(λf. λx. f (f x))  // Church numeral 2

// Compiles to interaction net:
@two = λf λx (f (f x))
```

### Parallel Reduction
```
// Automatic parallelization of:
// - Beta reduction
// - Pattern matching  
// - Recursive calls
// - Data structure operations
```

## Development Workflows

### HVM Development Protocol
```
/hvm.develop{
    intent="Build and optimize HVM programs",
    process=[
        /write{action="Write functional program"},
        /compile{action="Compile to interaction nets"},
        /optimize{action="Apply rewrite rules"},
        /execute{action="Run parallel reduction"},
        /profile{action="Analyze performance"}
    ]
}
```

### GPU Execution Protocol
```
/gpu.runtime{
    intent="Execute on GPU efficiently",
    process=[
        /allocate{action="GPU memory allocation"},
        /transfer{action="Host to device transfer"},
        /reduce{action="Parallel reduction"},
        /sync{action="Synchronize results"},
        /retrieve{action="Device to host transfer"}
    ]
}
```

## Integration with Autonogrammer Ecosystem

### Computational Backend
- **Bend Programs**: Primary execution runtime
- **Parallel Algorithms**: High-performance computing
- **AI Workloads**: Parallel model inference
- **Data Processing**: Stream processing pipelines

### Cross-Repository Synergies
- **Bend**: Primary language frontend
- **AI-Scientist**: Parallel experiment execution

# CLAUDE.md - HVM (Higher-order Virtual Machine) Configuration

HVM is a massively parallel functional runtime that achieves near-ideal speedup on GPUs and multi-core CPUs. It's based on Interaction Combinators and provides the backend for the Bend programming language.

## Project Overview

### Core Purpose
- **Optimal Reduction**: Beta-reduction in parallel without locks
- **Interaction Nets**: Graph-based computation model
- **GPU Native**: Runs directly on CUDA cores
- **Language Agnostic**: Can compile from multiple sources
- **Near-Linear Speedup**: Scales with available cores

### Project Structure
```
/src/                      # HVM core implementation
  /runtime/                # Runtime system
    /cpu/                  # CPU backend
    /gpu/                  # CUDA backend
  /compiler/               # HVM compiler
  /reducer/                # Reduction engine
  /memory/                 # Memory management
/hvm-lang/                 # HVM language frontend
/tests/                    # Test suite
/benchmarks/               # Performance benchmarks
```

## Interaction Combinators

### Core Concepts
```
// HVM uses interaction nets
// Nodes: Constructor, Duplicator, Eraser
// Rules: Annihilation, Commutation, Erasure

// Example: Lambda calculus encoding
(λf. λx. f (f x))  // Church numeral 2

// Compiles to interaction net:
@two = λf λx (f (f x))
```

### Parallel Reduction

// Automatic parallelization of:

// - Pattern matching  
// - Recursive calls
// - Data structure operations
